sn22.8:4.2: “Mendicants, I will teach you how grasping leads to anxiety, and how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.
sn22.8:4.3: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
sn22.8:4.4: And how does grasping lead to anxiety?
sn22.8:4.5: It’s when an uneducated ordinary person regards form like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn22.8:4.6: But that form of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:4.7: which gives rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:4.11: consciousness like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn22.8:4.12: But that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:4.13: which gives rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:4.14: That’s how grasping leads to anxiety.
sn22.8:5.1: And how does not grasping lead to freedom from anxiety?
sn22.8:5.2: It’s when an educated noble disciple regards form like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.8:5.3: When that form of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:5.4: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:5.8: consciousness like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.8:5.9: When that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:5.10: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:5.11: That’s how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.”
